body:
Seems like a fair thing to want to do. What seems like a good way to do this? Things that come to mind:

- Add some `without_url` method that returns some `impl Display` reference, kind of like how the `time` crate provides formatters.

  This would help directly when wanting to format, and could be done with references.
- Add `without_url` that consumes the error and drops the URL field completely.

  This would be useful to remove the URL once and prevent forgetting about it in other places. It couldn't be done with a reference, though.

There's probably other ways too, if you have an idea.

I'm really new to Rust so I don't know yet all the consequences of these options...

Maybe another option is to expose (in different namespaces) 2 implementations of the `Display` trait for the `Error` struct.
I believe this would be possible in Haskell and users could choose to import one or another into the current scope, but I don't know if it possible in Rust or if it is a nice pattern or not...

Anyway, even a simple `without_url(&self) -> String` method on the `Error` struct would be nice. I didn't manage to make one from outside the lib, but maybe there is way (?)

`fn without_url(&self) -> String` should have similar implementation as `Display for reqwest::Error` has.

What about `fn without_url(&self) -> Cow<Self>`? A method of `Error` which removes url.

issue.title: Allow removing URL information from Error

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

issue.body:
Fixes #297 by adding two new methods to `reqwest::Error`:
- ```rust
  /// Generate a printable error object which hides URL information.
  pub fn without_url(&self) -> impl fmt::Display
  ```
- ```rust
  /// Remove URL information from this error.
  pub fn delete_url(&mut self)
  ```

Adding both methods ensures that you can properly remove URL information no matter if you only have a (mutable) reference to an error, or if you own the error.

I added a unit test to ensure the correctness of the two methods.

issue.title: Add URL API to Error

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

issue.body:
Closes #297 by adding methods to manipulate the URL in `Error` (`url_mut`, `set_url`, `clear_url`, `without_url`, making `with_url` public) and methods to generate formatters (`as_url_masked` for `UrlMaskedError`, `as_url_hidden` for `UrlHiddenError`, `as_url_formatted` for `UrlFormattedError`) which implement `Display` on a borrowed `Error`.

Private formatting methods for kind (`write_kind`) and source (`write_source`) are added for consistency across formats, as well as `write_url_plain` and `write_url_masked` for different URL displays.

Finally, a test was added to make sure the formatters work as expected.

---

See also, #1299 for prior implementation of some of these

---

Note: The `set_url`/`clear_url` and `with_url`/`without_url` pairs are a bit redundant, though the ergonomics are different. I'd be open to removing one of those pairs to make things a little simpler.

issue.title: Add a new crate feature `strip-url-in-error`

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

issue.body:
Related issue #297 and PR #1442.

A method `without_url` was added earlier, which is useful for removing URL from a single Error to prevent leaking secrets. But in a Rust binary, most functions probably return `anyhow::Result<_>` instead of `Result<_, ConcreteError>` - the concrete error type is converted to a display type. To ensure that secrets are not leaked, users need to call `.map_err(|err| err.without_url())` for each `Result<_, reqwest::Error>`, which is inconvenient and easy to forget.

I propose to add a crate feature `strip-url-in-error`. when it is enabled, radically remove the `url` field from `reqwest::Error`, and remove the relevant methods (`url_mut`, `with_url` and `without_url`).
